node.title: Usage of ProjectionAux for the whole domain
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am currently using ProjectionAux to calculate the average of a variable for each element. Is there a way I can use it for all the elements - I need the average of the value for all the elements.
Just FYI - I know the average value (it is one of the constant global values in the input file). I need it to be used in a AuxKernel I wrote. This value does not change throughout the simulation. So, any other alternative way of handling it is also appreciated.
Thanks in advance,
Raghunandan.

Hello
You can set an auxvariable using a ParsedAux if you already know the value.
Computing a single value for the entire domain is more the role of a Postprocessor than an auxkernel. You should use something like this
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/ElementAverageValue.html
then use a ParsedAux to spread the value to a field, only if it's really needed

node.title: Calculation of logistic functions gives not-a-number (nan) errors or zero when it should increase from zero to unity.
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
I am trying to use logistic functions to add a function as a smooth sigmoid over a time period.  But the calculation of the function behaves erratically.
The function I would like to use in a ParsedFunction is:
expression = 'if(t<79500, 0, 1/(1 + exp((80000-t)/50) ) )'
But even if I start my solve at t = 79500 s, it fails immediately with:
`Time Step 1, time = 79510, dt = 10
Pre-SMO residual: -nan
Performing automatic scaling calculation
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_FNORM_NAN iterations 0
Solve Did NOT Converge!`
At t = 79500, exp((80000-t)/50) = exp(10) = 22026 which shouldn't be causing the NAN error.
So I've tried an alternative expression for the logistic function (without an if statement since for t<<80000, the exp term should tend to zero):
expression = '1 - (1/(1 + exp((t - 80000)/50)) )'
This code runs, but the value of the function calculated with this expression stays stuck at zero, even when t = 80500 and higher, where it should tend to unity.  This makes even less sense to me than the nan error.
However, if I let my solve start at t = 0 and use:
expression = '1/(1 + exp((500-t)/50) )'
then everything works fine.  The functions increases sigmoidally up to unity at about t = 1380 s and beyond.
So I can "force" it to work in this way and then append this bit of the solve to previous output up to 79500 s, but this is rather inelegant and time-consuming.
Why can the function expression cope when the logistic function mid-point is at 500s, but not at 80000 s (for t>79500 s), even though the range of values of the argument of the exp function is the same?
Is there some setting I can change to get the solve to work around 80000 s?

Hello
Thanks for reporting this. This must be an issue in the parser, we use this
http://warp.povusers.org/FunctionParser/fparser.html
Would you mind checking if they mention any overflow issue in their documentation?
Guillaume

Hi
Thanks for the quick reply.
I'm not sure what I'd be looking for in the document at that link as I'm not fluent in C++ or understanding all the details of the calculations that go on behind the scenes.
I sort of assume that MOOSE would "do the math" for the functions I put in.  Hence my confusion that it didn't.
Ed

It does say this, which seems it could be relevant:

"(Note that currently the exponentiation operator is not supported for FunctionParser_li nor FunctionParser_gmpint. With the former the result would very easily overflow, making its usefulness questionable. With the latter it could be easily abused to make the program run out of memory; think of a function like "10^10^10^100000".) "
Mind you, that means exponentiation as raising to powers, not the exponential function.  So probably not relevant after all.

Here are the only other mentions of "overflow":

However, the library can not guarantee that it will catch all possible floating point errors before performing them, because this is impossible to do with standard C++. For example, dividing a very large value by a value which is very close to zero, or calculating the logarithm of a very small value may overflow the result, as well as multiplying two very large values. Raising a negative number to a non-integral power may cause a NaN result, etc.
As a rule of thumb, the library will (by default) detect invalid operations if they are invalid for a range of values. For example, square root is undefined for all negative values, and arc sine is undefined only values outside the range [-1, 1]. In general, operations which are invalid for only one single value (rather than a contiguous range of values) will not be detected (division by the exact value of zero is an exception to this rule) nor will overflow/underflow situations.

ok thanks for searching the documentation. There is not a strong hint that the exponentials are not evaluated as we would expect.
could you try this by any chance?
expression = '1 - (1/(1 + exp( ((t - 80000)/50)))  )'

In case it's optimizing by doing something like
exp(t/50) exp(- 80000)/50)
which would obviously be problematic

I'll aim to give this a try in the next day or two.  If I understand it right, including the extra set of brackets may force the parser to process the calculations in a different order.
But for now I'm able to carry on with my workaround, see below.

That is what I am thinking yes
ok I am glad. We'll need to work in FParser to fix this. @dschwen thoughts?

Trying
expression = '1 - (1/(1 + exp( ((t - 80000)/50)))  )'
didn't work.
The value of the function stays at zero even for t = 84700, the end time of my model.

I'm going to try a workaround where I set time t in the MOOSE model to be the actual value starting at 79500, but define a function:
tdash = t - 79500
which I can use in the argument of the exponential term of the logistic function.
But a more robust solution would be welcome if anyone can suggest one.
A quick update, this seems to have worked.  I've now managed to run my model to the end and the increasing sigmoidal logistic function worked perfectly.

For clarity, here's what I'm using which gives the desired output:
  [tdash_fn]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = 't-79500'  
  []
  [H_time_smooth_fn]
    type = ParsedFunction
    symbol_names = 'tdash'
    symbol_values = 'tdash_fn'
    expression = 'if(t<79500, 0, 1 - 1/(1+exp((tdash-500)/50)) )'
  []

Or a bit more straightforward:
  [tdash_fn]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = 't-80000'  
  []
  [H_time_smooth_fn]
    type = ParsedFunction
    symbol_names = 'tdash'
    symbol_values = 'tdash_fn'
    expression = 'if(t<79500, 0, 1 - 1/(1+exp(tdash/50)) )'
  []

node.title: Inactive Subdomain with no variables and kernels
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose Community,
I have created a very simple Moose model in which the elements of a subdomain are to be moved to an “inactive” subdomain. Following the recommendation in #28092, I tried to block-restrict all variables and kernels away from my inactive subdomain. When I run this model, Moose will not converge:
Time Step 3, time = 0.101, dt = 0.001

  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_PC_FAILED iterations 0
                 PC failed due to FACTOR_NUMERIC_ZEROPIVOT 
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH iterations 0
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge

When I add some MatDiffusion kernels, the model converges.
My questions are:

How can I check which variables and kernels are active on which subdomains?
A nuance asked differently: How can I see what is active (kernels, variables, ...) on a given subdomain?
The variables disp_x, disp_y, and disp_z seem to be present in my inactive domain. Is there my problem? If yes, should I block-restrict them as well?

  use_displaced_mesh = false
[]

Box1_inactive_name = 'Box1_inactive'
inactive_domain_block_names = '${Box1_inactive_name}'

[Problem]

  kernel_coverage_check = SKIP_LIST
  kernel_coverage_block_list = '${inactive_domain_block_names}'
  material_coverage_check = SKIP_LIST
  material_coverage_block_list = '${inactive_domain_block_names}'
[]

[Mesh]

    dim = 3
    nx = 6
    ny = 6
    nz = 2

    xmax = +3
    ymin = -3
    ymax = +3
    zmin = -2
    zmax = +2

    block_id = 1
    location = "INSIDE"
    bottom_left = "-1.0 -1.0 -0.0"
    top_right = "+1.0 +1.0 +2.0"
  []

  add_subdomain_names = '${inactive_domain_block_names}'
[]

      []
    []
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [dummy]
    type = MooseVariableFVReal

  []

# fix the lower model boundary in y and z direction
[BCs]

    type = DirichletBC

# fix the left mdoel boundary in x direction

# Material: Volume Elements
[Materials]

[Executioner]

  [TimeSteppers]
    [BlockEventTimeStepper]
      type = TimeSequenceStepper

    []
  []

  solve_type = 'PJFNK'

How can I check which variables and kernels are active on which subdomains?

One way is to use Debug/show_execution_order and see what kernel is active on what subdomain

The variables disp_x, disp_y, and disp_z seem to be present in my inactive domain. Is there my problem? If yes, should I block-restrict them as well?

Absolutely.
If they are present on domains that there is no equation for them, then the nullspace is the entire space, and most solvers will not like this.

Thanks for pointing to Debug/show_execution_order. If I interpret the output correctly, there are no kernels on block 2 (as expected, since I do not request kernels for this block in the input file). But I dont see block-coverage of the variables?
Time Step 3, time = 0.101, dt = 0.001
[DBG] Computing elemental user objects on TIMESTEP_BEGIN
[DBG] Ordering of User Objects on block 0
[DBG] Executing ElementUserObject on TIMESTEP_BEGIN
[DBG] Order of execution:
[DBG] GlobalSubdomainModifier
                             
[DBG] Only user objects active on local element/sides are executed
[DBG] Ordering of User Objects on block 2
[DBG] Executing ElementUserObject on TIMESTEP_BEGIN
[DBG] Order of execution:
[DBG] GlobalSubdomainModifier
                             
[DBG] Only user objects active on local element/sides are executed
[DBG] Beginning elemental loop to compute Residual on LINEAR
[DBG] Ordering of Residual Objects on block BaseMesh (0)
[DBG] Ordering of kernels:
[DBG] TM_bla0 TM_bla1 TM_bla2
[DBG] Ordering of Residual Objects on block Box1_inactive (2)
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 4.150026e+01

Digging a little deeper:
If I read the code correctly that adds the displacement variables, Moose does not seem to apply the block constraints to the variables created. Therefore, disp_x, disp_y, and disp_z are also active for all my inactive domains. Is this assessment correct?

  
    
      moose/modules/solid_mechanics/src/physics/QuasiStaticSolidMechanicsPhysics.C
    
    
        Lines 385 to 402
      in
      26a0eda
    
  
  
    

        
          
           if (getParam<bool>("add_variables")) 
        

        
          
           { 
        

        
          
             auto params = _factory.getValidParams("MooseVariable"); 
        

        
          
             // determine necessary order 
        

        
          
             const bool second = _problem->mesh().hasSecondOrderElements(); 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
             params.set<MooseEnum>("order") = second ? "SECOND" : "FIRST"; 
        

        
          
             params.set<MooseEnum>("family") = "LAGRANGE"; 
        

        
          
             if (isParamValid("scaling")) 
        

        
          
               params.set<std::vector<Real>>("scaling") = {getParam<Real>("scaling")}; 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
             // Loop through the displacement variables 
        

        
          
             for (const auto & disp : _displacements) 
        

        
          
             { 
        

        
          
               // Create displacement variables 
        

        
          
               _problem->addVariable("MooseVariable", disp, params); 
        

        
          
             } 
        

        
          
           } 
        
    
  


Just from the syntax of the [Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic]-block I'd assume Moose is only adding this varibales to the subdomains given in the blocks parameter:
[Physics]
  [SolidMechanics]
    [QuasiStatic]
      [bla]
        strain = SMALL
        incremental = true
        add_variables = true
        generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_yy stress_zz'
        block = 'BaseMesh Box1'
      []
    []
  []
[]

Would it make sense to hand-down the block restriction of [Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic] to the variables it creates?
If the answer to this question is 'yes' some things are unclear to me. Please assume a hypothetical model:

With a [Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic], disp_x, disp_y and disp_z variables are only created for subdomain “A” (e.g. for 3D-volume elements)
The user also needs the variables disp_x, disp_y and disp_z and others (rotXYZ variables...) for a subdomain “B” with e.g. shell elements. The user must then create these variables explicitly with [Variables]...[].
Does this mean that Moose creates 2x the variables disp_x, disp_y and disp_z? Or does Mosse automatically merge these variables?

Moose does not automatically merge two variables
And defining them twice won't work because you'll get an error.
Imo you need to add an option to not define the variables inside the Physics, then perform that part manually

Ok, without changing the code of Moose, I have to fall back to “add_variables = false” and add the disp-variables by hand with "correct" block restriction.
Would the following behavior be desirable if “add_variables = true” is set in [Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic]?
[Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic] checks whether the disp variables are already defined in the model. If not, these variables are added with bock-restriction. If the variables already exist and have a block-restriction, the existing block-restriction from [Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic] is added.
This seems fine to me

Now I got a little problem.
If I define the variable disp_x above the [Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic] block, I can dedect this variable in QuasiStaticSolidMechanicsPhysics.C using
if (_problem->hasVariable(disp)) ...

The corresponding input file:
# ===== Variables: Displacements =====
[Variables]
  [disp_x]
    order = SECOND
    family = LAGRANGE
    block = 'BaseMesh'
  []
  ...
[]

[Physics]
  [SolidMechanics]
    [QuasiStatic]
      [all]
        strain = SMALL
        incremental = true
        add_variables = true
        generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_yy stress_zz'
        block = 'Box1'
      []
    []
  []
[]

If I have the [Variables] block below the [Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic] block, _problem->hasVariable(disp) returns false.
Fun fact: Moose does not complain that add_variables is true and disp_x already exists regardless of where which block is located! I think this is because:

  
    
      moose/framework/src/problems/FEProblemBase.C
    
    
         Line 2562
      in
      468ab73
    
  
  
    

        
          
           if (duplicateVariableCheck(var_name, fe_type, /* is_aux = */ false)) 
        
    
  


One option would be to force the user to define Variables before [Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic]. This would add constraints to the design of the input files. I do not like this option much, but it would ease implementing this issue.
In search of other options: Is there a way to detect and modify variables defined after the [Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic] block (I'd need to merge the block-restriction of [Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic])

Hello
If a task has to happen before the task that adds the variables of the physics, then in the ...App.C file (SolidMechanics most likely) the dependency between the two tasks should be indicated.
If you add Debug/show_actions=true you can see the order in which the tasks of each action are performed.
Within the same task, the order in the input file matters
Guillaume

Dear Guillaume,
I need to come byck to one of my initial questions:

How can I check which variables and kernels are active on which subdomains?

For Kernels you gave:

One way is to use Debug/show_execution_order and see what kernel is active on what subdomain

How about variables? How can I find out in which blocks a variable is defined?

We don't have that in moose.
Feel free to add Debug/show_block_restriction to moose if you need it

The name show_block_restriction would suggest to show more than just "what variables are defined per block".
So the output of show_block_restriction may look like:
Subdomain 'BaseMesh' (0):
    Variables (3): disp_x, disp_y, disp_z
    AuxVariables (1): dummy_aux_var

Subdomain 'TheOtherBlock' (1):
    Variables (3): disp_x, disp_y, disp_z
    AuxVariables (2): dummy_aux_var, another_aux_var

Beside Variables and AuxVariables other objects may be shown.
Would that be in the spirit of a debug option show_block_restriction?

Yes I think this would make be good to do this for all the different systems in use and block-restricted
Alternatively, the code could detect groups of blocks that are shared between groups of objects. This would limit the output.
However because this is for debug purposes it's not needed now
@YaqiWang dont you have that in griffin?

node.title: 2D Mesh Extrusion
node.bodyText: Is it possible to create a AnnularMeshGenerator generated mesh with differing mesh bias at the ID and OD of the geometry? If so can that 2D mesh be extruded with bias from the origin that decreases (decreased mesh growth} with each subsequent level of mesh height?

Hello
The AdvancedMeshExtruder will let you extrude with different axial layer thicknesses.
There are numerous circular mesh generator. I'm sure there is one with a radial biasing option
Guillaume

https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/PolygonConcentricCircleMeshGenerator.html will let you pick ring sizes.
Just delete the regions outside the cylinder using a BlockDeletionGenerator after

Thank you. I was able to do what I had asked by using two instances of AnnularMeshGenerator, one to make an outer ring with negative bias and the other to make an inner ring with positive bias. I then used StitchedMeshGenerator to combine the two coincident surfaces, removing the previous surface names. I extruded the mesh using AdvancedExtruderGenerator, with bias.
I'm glad. Thanks for reporting back about it!

node.title: Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_FUNCTION_DOMAIN iterations 0
node.bodyText:
Hello,
My residual is blowing up, and as a result, I’m getting the following convergence error:
Exceeded maximum iterations in material return mapping iterations.
At element 0 _qp=0 Coordinates (x,y,z)=(0.0704416, 0.0704416, 0.0704416) block=0
In 1000 iterations the residual went from 7.97616 to -2.18199e-07 in '_L2creep'.

Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH iterations 0
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge

I tried to diagnose this problem by following ticket #22879. Essentially, I set the iteration debug output (i.e., internal_solve_full_iteration_history = true) and got the following:
Time Step 1, time = 1, dt = 1
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 9.523810e+04
      0 Linear |R| = 9.523810e+04

In 1000 iterations the residual went from 1.99197 to 0.0427207 in '_L2creep'.

Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH iterations 0
 Solve Did NOT Converge!

(Note: I showed only the first 50 and the last 50 iterations here.)
I vary the error tolerances a bit by setting nl_rel_tol = 1e-8 and nl_abs_tol = 1e-11, but I'm still getting the convergence error. Please, help. What error tolerance will you recommend? Thanks.

Hello
Can you first turn off the linear search
In [Executioner], line_search = none
You could tighten the linear solve tolerance, I suspect the calculation that fails here is the 2nd nonlinear iteration residual calculation
Guillaume

Ok, thanks, @GiudGiud . I think I may have found the solution. My moose (numerical) solution now matches my analytical solution for Lubby2, as you can see below. There is a slight deviation between 5 to 10 days, but it's fine. The only thing is that I got these results by multiplying my numerical results by a factor of 0.1. My analytical solution is in percentage (i.e., I multiplied the actual results by 100%). In reality, I should be multiplying my numerical results too by 100%. It shows that my numerical results are higher than the analytical solution by a factor of 1000. I don't know if I have to implement a correction factor somewhere or not. If you could help with a suggestion, that would be awesome. Thanks.

Hi
I dont have any insight on why they would be different that much.
I would double check the units of both the analytical and numerical model.
Maybe plot other quantities that you can obtain analytically and see if everything agrees well / where the difference appears
Guillaume
Thanks, Guillaume. I’ll consider it and let you know shortly.
Yeah, I found the bug...Thanks @GiudGiud

node.title: Multiapps coupling problem
node.bodyText:
Since the convergence of thermal-mechanical coupling is not good when calculated separately, I want to put the stress field and temperature field into two cards to calculate and use multiapp to transfer, hoping to improve the convergence. It is possible to calculate each card separately, but the first step after using multiapp will report that the error has been killed. What is the problem with my settings and how can I improve it?

node.title: Problems with the using AreaPostprocessor on a Generated Mesh
node.bodyText: I created a mesh using two instances of AnnularMeshGenerator, that I then stitched, using StitchedMeshGenerato, which I the extruded using AdvancedExtruderGenerator, with bias. I attempted to determine the surface area of the endpoint of the generated mesh with the AreaPostprocessor. It did not work. On previous .e file the AreaPostprocessor worked fine. Any ideas of why it does not work with the generated mesh?

The culprit was me using find and replace, to replace my previous named boundaries with the new generated boundary names that replaced words with numbers. The use of numbers in the names of the postprocessors seem to have been the issue.

node.title: Mesh reset occurs with change in step or time period
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello everyone,
I am running a simulation to form a rectangular hollow section (RHS) from a circular hollow section (CHS). Rollers are used, top and side, and then I would like to rotate the rollers along the length of the CHS. My issue is that the rollers are reset into their original position after the displacement step. I have tried StepPeriod as well as TimePeriod without success. The input file is provided below and I would be very grateful for any advice on how to get this going. As a side note, I used DisplacementAboutAxis for the rotation but when executed on the deformed mesh using use_displaced_mesh = true the rollers turn in on themselves, so I used ParsedFunction of my own for the rotation.
Many thanks,
JW
# This test case creates a rectangular hollow section (RHS)
# from a circular hollow section (CHS). 

[GlobalParams]
  volumetric_locking_correction = true
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]

[Mesh]
  [mFile]
   # Read mesh from file
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = roller_form_hex8_move30_4_thin_coarse.e
  []

  [create_sideset]
    type = SideSetsFromNodeSetsGenerator
    input = mFile
  []

   length_unit = m
   patch_update_strategy = iteration
   patch_size = 20
   allow_renumbering = true

[Functions]
  [stress_strain_curve_steel]
    # Stress Strain Curve for Plastic material (steel)
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0.000 0.012 0.050 0.100 0.150 0.200 0.280'
    y = '185.0e6 225.0e6 290.0e6 340.0e6 370.0e6 385.0e6 405.0e6'
  []
  [stress_strain_curve_al]
    # Stress Strain Curve for Plastic material (steel)
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0.000  0.002  0.025   0.050    0.075  0.100   0.150    0.175'
    y = '75.0e6 82.0e6 116.0e6 140.0e6  150e6  162.0e6 164.0e6 168.0e6'
  []

  [roller_step1]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0    0.0250    0.0500    0.0750    0.1000    0.1250    0.1500    0.1750    0.2000    0.2250    0.2500   0.3000  0.5000  1.0000  2.0000  3.0000'
    y = '0    0.1000    0.2000    0.3000    0.4000    0.5000    0.6000    0.7000    0.8000    0.9000    1.0000   1.0000  1.0000  1.0000  1.0000  1.0000'
  []
  [roller_step2]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0.2500     0.4792    0.7083    0.9375    1.1667    1.3958    1.6250    1.8542    2.0833    2.3125    2.5417    2.7708    3.0000'
    #y = '1.000      1.0833    1.1667    1.2500    1.3333    1.4167    1.5000    1.5833    1.6667    1.7500    1.8333    1.9167    2.0000'
    y = '0.000     0.0833    0.1667    0.2500    0.3333    0.4167    0.5000    0.5833    0.6667    0.7500    0.8333    0.9167    1.0000'
  []

  [disp_roller_step1]  # Roller initial displacement that forms RHS in Step 1
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = 'vDisp * roller_step1' #* 4*t'
    symbol_names = 'vDisp roller_step1'
    symbol_values = '-6.0e-3 roller_step1'
  []

  [disp_CHS_step2] # Displacement of RHS CHS through rollers in Step 2
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = 'alpha2 * roller_step2'#(0.3636*t-0.909)'
    symbol_names = 'alpha2 roller_step2' 
    symbol_values = '-238.0e-3 roller_step2'
  []


  [x_rotation]
    type = ParsedFunction
    #expression = '(x0*cos(angle*pi/180) - y0*sin(angle*pi/180) - x0)'
    expression =  '(x - x0)*(cos(alpha*angle*pi/180*roller_step2)-1) - (y - y0)*sin(alpha*angle*pi/180*roller_step2)'
    symbol_names = 'alpha angle roller_step2 x0 y0'
    symbol_values = '-1 120 roller_step2 0.029999999931746  0.07100000'
  []
  
  [y_rotation]
    type = ParsedFunction
    #expression = '(y0*cos(angle*pi/180) + x0*sin(angle*pi/180) - y0)'
    expression = '((x - x0)*sin(alpha*angle*pi/180*roller_step2) + (y - y0)*(cos(alpha*angle*pi/180*roller_step2)-1))'
    symbol_names = 'alpha angle roller_step2 x0 y0'
    symbol_values = '-1 120 roller_step2 0.029999999931746  0.07100000'
  []

  [z_rotation]
    type = ParsedFunction
    #expression = '(y0*cos(angle*pi/180) + x0*sin(angle*pi/180) - y0)'
    expression = '((x - x0)*sin(alpha*angle*pi/180*roller_step2) + (z - z0)*(cos(alpha*angle*pi/180*roller_step2)-1))'
    symbol_names = 'alpha angle roller_step2 x0 z0'
    symbol_values = '-1 120 roller_step2 0.029999999931746  0.07100000'
  []

 # Centroid locations of rollers prior to vertical move

[BCs]
  # STEP 1

  # Boundary Conditions - TRoller

  # No x or z displacement of TRoller
  [bc_fixed01_TRoller]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    preset = false
    boundary = 'BCTRoller'
    value = 0.0
  []
  [bc_fixed02_TRoller]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    #use_displaced_mesh = true 
    preset = false
    boundary = 'BCTRoller'
    value = 0.0
  []

  # Movement of TRoller to form RHS
  [bc_disp01_TRoller]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    preset = true
    #use_displaced_mesh = true 
    boundary = 'BCTRoller'
    function = disp_roller_step1
  []


  # Boundary Conditions - SRoller

  # No x or y displacement of SRoller
  [bc_fixed01_SRoller]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    preset = false
    boundary = 'BCSRoller'
    value = 0.0
  []
  [bc_fixed02_SRoller]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    #use_displaced_mesh = true 
    preset = false
    boundary = 'BCSRoller'
    value = 0.0
  []

  # Movement of SRoller to form RHS
  [bc_disp01_SRoller]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    preset = false
    boundary = 'BCSRoller'
    function = disp_roller_step1
  []

  # Boundary Conditions - CHS

  # Fixity on free end of CHS as well as Y and Z symmetry faces
  
  [bc_fixed01_CHS]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    preset = false
    boundary = 'XDispCHS'
    value = 0.0
  []
  [bc_fixed02_CHS]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    preset = false
    boundary = 'ZSymmetryCHS'
    value = 0.0
  []
  [bc_fixed03_CHS]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    preset = false
    boundary = 'YSymmetryCHS'
    value = 0.0
  []


  # STEP 2

  # Boundary Conditions - TRoller

  # Rotation in the y and z direction of the TRoller

  [rotate_x_TRoller]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'BCTRoller'
    function = x_rotation
    preset = false
    use_displaced_mesh = false
  []
  
  [rotate_y_TRoller]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 'BCTRoller'
    function = y_rotation
    preset = false
    use_displaced_mesh = false
  []

  # Fix displacement in z direction as part of rotation
  # [bc_fixed02_TRoller]

  # Boundary Conditions - SRoller

  # Rotation in the x and z direction of the SRoller
  [rotate_x_SRoller]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'BCSRoller'
    function = x_rotation
    preset = false
    use_displaced_mesh = false
  []
  
  [rotate_z_SRoller]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = 'BCSRoller'
    function = z_rotation
    preset = false
    use_displaced_mesh = false
  []

  # Fix displacement in y direction as part of rotation
  # [bc_fixed02_SRoller]


  # Boundary Conditions - CHS

  [bc_disp01_CHS]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    use_displaced_mesh = true 
    preset = false
    boundary = 'XDispCHS'
    function = disp_CHS_step2
  []
  # [bc_fixed02_CHS]
  # [bc_fixed03_CHS]

  [disp_CHS_step2] # Displacement of RHS CHS through rollers in Step 2
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = 'alpha2 * roller_step2'
    symbol_names = 'alpha2 roller_step2' 
    symbol_values = '-238.0e-3 roller_step2'
  []


  [x_rotation]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression =  '(x - x0)*(cos(alpha*angle*pi/180*roller_step2)-1) - (y - y0)*sin(alpha*angle*pi/180*roller_step2)'
    symbol_names = 'alpha angle roller_step2 x0 y0'
    symbol_values = '-1 120 roller_step2 0.029999999931746  0.07100000'
  []

  [x_rotationS]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression =  '(x - x0)*(cos(alpha*angle*pi/180*roller_step2)-1) - (z - z0)*sin(alpha*angle*pi/180*roller_step2)'
    symbol_names = 'alpha angle roller_step2 x0 z0'
    symbol_values = '-1 120 roller_step2 0.029999999931746  0.07100000'
  []
  
  [y_rotation]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = '((x - x0)*sin(alpha*angle*pi/180*roller_step2) + (y - y0)*(cos(alpha*angle*pi/180*roller_step2)-1))'
    symbol_names = 'alpha angle roller_step2 x0 y0'
    symbol_values = '-1 120 roller_step2 0.029999999931746  0.07100000'
  []

  [z_rotation]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = '((x - x0)*sin(alpha*angle*pi/180*roller_step2) + (z - z0)*(cos(alpha*angle*pi/180*roller_step2)-1))'
    symbol_names = 'alpha angle roller_step2 x0 z0'
    symbol_values = '-1 120 roller_step2 0.029999999931746  0.07100000'
  []


  # TRoller conditions
  # disp_x
  [disp_TRoller_x]
    type = ParsedFunction
    # expression = 'if(t < step2_time, step1_disp, if(t<step3_time, step2_disp, something_else_for_the_rest))'
    expression = 'if(t<${step2_time},0,x_rotation)'
    symbol_names =  'x_rotation'
    symbol_values = 'x_rotation'
  []

  # disp_y
  [disp_TRoller_y]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = 'if(t<${step2_time},disp_roller_step1,y_rotation)'
    symbol_names = 'disp_roller_step1 y_rotation'
    symbol_values = 'disp_roller_step1 y_rotation'
   []

   [disp_SRoller_x]
    type = ParsedFunction
    # expression = 'if(t < step2_time, step1_disp, if(t<step3_time, step2_disp, something_else_for_the_rest))'
    expression = 'if(t<${step2_time},0,x_rotationS)'
    symbol_names =  'x_rotationS'
    symbol_values = 'x_rotationS'
  []

  # disp_z
  [disp_SRoller_z]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = 'if(t<${step2_time},disp_roller_step1,z_rotation)'
    symbol_names = 'disp_roller_step1 z_rotation'
    symbol_values = 'disp_roller_step1 z_rotation'
   []

  # disp_x - CHS
  [disp_CHS_x]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression =    'if(t<${step2_time},0,disp_CHS_step2)'
    symbol_names =  'disp_CHS_step2'
    symbol_values = 'disp_CHS_step2'
   []   
[]

[Materials]
  [elasticity_tensor_steel]
    # Creates the elasticity tensor using steel parameters
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 210e9 # Pa
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
    block = 'TROLLER SROLLER'
  []
  [stress]
    # Computes the stress, using linear elasticity
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
    block = 'TROLLER SROLLER'
  []
  [elasticity_tensor]
    # Creates the elasticity tensor using aluminnium parameters
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 68e9 # Pa
    poissons_ratio = 0.33
    block = 'CHS'
  []
  [isotropic_plasticity]
    type = IsotropicPlasticityStressUpdate
    yield_stress = 75.0e6
    hardening_function = stress_strain_curve_al
    block = 'CHS'
  []
  [radial_return_stress]
    type = ComputeMultipleInelasticStress
    tangent_operator = elastic
    inelastic_models = 'isotropic_plasticity'
    block = 'CHS'
  []
  [density_steel]
    # Defines the density of steel
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'density'
    prop_values = '7850' # kg/m^3
    block = 'TROLLER SROLLER CHS'
  []
[]

 # Centroid locations of rollers prior to vertical move
 #                x                       y                      z 
 # SRoller    0.029999999931746      -0.006                 0.0770000003174603
 # TRoller    0.029999999931746       0.0770000003174603       0.006    

[BCs]
  # STEP 1

  # Boundary Conditions - TRoller

  # Step 1 - No x displacement of TRoller
  # Step 2 - Rotation in x of TRoller

  [bc_fixed01_TRoller]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    #preset = false
    boundary = 'BCTRoller'
    function = disp_TRoller_x
  []

  # Step 1 - No z displacement of TRoller
  # Step 2 - No z displacement of TRoller

  [bc_fixed02_TRoller]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    #use_displaced_mesh = true 
    #preset = false
    boundary = 'BCTRoller'
    value = 0.0
  []

  # Step 1 - Vertical y displacement of TRoller
  # Step 2 - Rotation in y of TRoller

  # Movement of TRoller to form RHS
  [bc_disp01_TRoller]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    #preset = true
    #use_displaced_mesh = true 
    boundary = 'BCTRoller'
    function = disp_TRoller_y
  []


  # Boundary Conditions - SRoller

  # Step 1 - No x displacement of SRoller
  # Step 2 - Rotation in x of SRoller

  [bc_fixed01_SRoller]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    #preset = false
    boundary = 'BCSRoller'
    function = disp_SRoller_x
  []

  # Step 1 - No y displacement of SRoller
  # Step 2 - No y displacement of SRoller

  [bc_fixed02_SRoller]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    #use_displaced_mesh = true 
    #preset = false
    boundary = 'BCSRoller'
    value = 0.0
  []


  # Step 1 - Horizontal z displacement of SRoller
  # Step 2 - Rotation in z of SRoller

  # Movement of SRoller to form RHS
  [bc_disp01_SRoller]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    #preset = false
    boundary = 'BCSRoller'
    function = disp_SRoller_z
  []

  # Boundary Conditions - CHS

  # Step 1 - Fixity on free end of CHS 
  # Step 2 - Horizontal displacement on free end of CHS

  [bc_disp01_CHS]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    #use_displaced_mesh = true 
    preset = false
    boundary = 'XDispCHS'
    function = disp_CHS_x
  []
  
  # Step 1 - Fixity on Y and Z symmetry faces
  # Step 2 - Fixity on Y and Z symmetry faces

  [bc_fixed02_CHS]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    #preset = false
    boundary = 'ZSymmetryCHS'
    value = 0.0
  []
  [bc_fixed03_CHS]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    #preset = false
    boundary = 'YSymmetryCHS'
    value = 0.0
  []
[]

[Contact]
    [troller_chs]
      primary = TRoller_Contact
      secondary = CHS_Contact
      friction_coefficient = 0.4
      model = coulomb
      formulation = mortar_penalty
      penalty = 68e9
      penalty_friction = 1e4
      use_dual = false
    []
    [sroller_chs]
      primary = SRoller_Contact
      secondary = CHS_Contact
      friction_coefficient = 0.4
      model = coulomb
      formulation = mortar_penalty
      penalty = 68e9
      penalty_friction = 1e4
      use_dual = false
    []
[]
  
[Dampers]
  [contact_slip01]
    type = ContactSlipDamper
    primary = 'TRoller_Contact SRoller_Contact'
    secondary = 'CHS_Contact CHS_Contact'
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]


[Controls]
  [step1]
    # This step covers the formation of the RHS
    type = TimePeriod
    # Enable only BCs that move the rollers
    enable_objects =  'TimeStepper::step1DT'
    disable_objects = 'TimeStepper::step2DT'
    reverse_on_false = false
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
    start_time = '0'
    end_time = ${transition_time}
    #step_user_object = step_uo
    set_sync_times = true
    #step_number = 0
  []
  [step2]
    # This step covers the formation of the RHS
    type = TimePeriod
    # Enable only BCs that move the rollers
    enable_objects  = 'TimeStepper::step2DT'
    disable_objects = 'TimeStepper::step1DT'
    reverse_on_false = false
    #depends_on = 'step1'
    execute_on = 'timestep_end'
    start_time = ${transition_time}
    end_time = '4.00'
    #step_user_object = step_uo
    set_sync_times = true
    #step_number = 1
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  scheme = 'crank-nicolson'
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'

  petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason -ksp_converged_reason -snes_ksp_ew'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_type -pc_factor_shift_type 
  -pc_factor_shift_amount '
  petsc_options_value = 'lu mumps NONZERO 1e-15'
  
  
  reuse_preconditioner = true
  reuse_preconditioner_max_linear_its = 25

  line_search_package = petsc

  # Taken from frictionless_penalty_contact_line_search.i
  line_search = 'contact'
  contact_line_search_ltol = .5
  contact_line_search_allowed_lambda_cuts = 0

  # Total simulation time
  end_time = 1.00
  # Minimum and maximum time step sizes
  dtmin = 1e-15
  dtmax = 0.1

  # Auto time stepping (similar to Abaqus and CalculiX)
  [TimeSteppers]
    [step1DT]
      type = IterationAdaptiveDT
      # Initial time step size
      reset_dt = true
      dt = 0.001
      optimal_iterations = 6
      iteration_window = 2
      growth_factor = 1.2
      cutback_factor = 0.8
    []
    [step2DT ]
      type = IterationAdaptiveDT #ConstantDT
      # Initial time step size
      reset_dt = true
      dt = 1e-9
      optimal_iterations = 6
      iteration_window = 2
      growth_factor = 1.2
      cutback_factor = 0.8
    []
  []
 
  # Non-linear solver settings
  nl_rel_tol = 1.5e-06
  nl_abs_tol = 1.5e-06 # 6 if no friction
  l_tol = 1e-3
  l_max_its = 60
  nl_max_its = 50
  automatic_scaling = true
  #automatic_scaling_function = scaling_function
[]

[Outputs]
  perf_graph = true
  csv = false
  [out]
    type = Exodus
    #elemental_as_nodal = true
  []
[]

it seems some elements are getting distorted too strongly and have a negative volume now
   volume()=-5.26751e-05

you'll need to limit or apply more uniformly the displacements to prevent that

Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A Getting Started is the most appropriate category for my question (trouble installing, beginner user, ...)
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (avoid screenshots if possible, triple back quotes before/after pasted text, etc)

Issue or question about MOOSE
I have successfully installed MOOSE once before through CONDA, I want to install MOOSE with HIP support now, I have installed petsc with HIP support now. But don't know how to make MOOSE use this petsc directly. At the same time, the petsc I installed is less STRUMPACK than the petsc MOOSE downloaded by default. I wonder how this will affect my subsequent work? Or is the STRUMPACK a must for MOOSE?
Diagnostics for MOOSE installation issues
No response

Hello
strumpack is not necessary for MOOSE
You can specify the PETSC_DIR then follow instructions for HPC installs of moose starting at libmesh
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html
Guillaume
I want to install MOOSE offline. Can I start from libmesh as well?

For libMesh, you can gather all the necessary bits by cloning libMesh and then performing a recursive submodule update command. Afterwards, you can transfer what was created to your air-gaped/offline machine and finish up with configure; make routines:
cd moose
git submodule update --init --recursive libmesh
tar -pzcf libmesh.tar.gz libmesh
<copy libmesh.tar.gz to where it needs to go>
cd moose
tar -xf /some/path/where/you/copied/libmesh.tar.gz -C .
After this, you can enter the libmesh directory, and perform your desired configure/build:
mkdir libmesh/build
cd libmesh/build
export PETSC_DIR=/where/ever/PETSc/is
../configure --prefix='/some/final/resting/location' --methods="opt" etc etc
If you wish to use the same configuration otherwise used by our update_and_rebuild scripts, please take a look at:
moose/scripts/configure_libmesh.sh

node.title: Mesh Adaptivity for a set of vector variables
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hi,
I am working on simulating polarization in ferroelectric thin films utilizing and was wondering if it is possible to have a marker operate on a set of vector variables (polar_x, polar_y, polar_z) or possibly even the norm of the vector represented as an AuxVariable (something along the lines of VectorThresholdMarker).
I have been unsuccessful trying to create such a custom Marker from scratch as when I try to add the three polar variables, as coupledValue, the compile throws an error that it does not recognize coupledValue.
In these simulations I need a fine mesh at the start for polar domains to form from the paralectric state and as they materialize, I would like for the mesh to coarsen within each domain, shown below:

In this case pictured the coarsening is happening on the polar_z variable.  I can't just use a ComboMarker as all three polar variables exist on every point in the mesh and if the marker operating on polar_z marks for COARSEN, the markers for polar_x and polar_y will mark for REFINE and my understanding is that REFINE will always take precedence over COARSEN.
Additionally I was wondering if max_h_level can be block restricted.
Thanks

I would use https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/VectorVariableComponentAux.html or https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/VectorVariableMagnitudeAux.html , which will get you an auxvariable that other markers would work on. Or use coupledVectorValue to get the vector variable in your custom marker.

The formulation used in the Ferret application utilizes three separate LAGRANGE variables for each vector component as opposed to one variable that is considered a vector.  I don't believe this approach would work for use in these simulations, but what Marker can utilize an AuxVariable instead of a Variable?

Think I am a bit lost.

I am working on simulating polarization in ferroelectric thin films utilizing and was wondering if it is possible to have a marker operate on a set of vector variables (polar_x, polar_y, polar_z) or possibly even the norm of the vector represented as an AuxVariable (something along the lines of VectorThresholdMarker).

So it's not a "Vector Variable", instead you have 3 "regular" variables?  There are a few different auxkernels that can perform operations on sets of variables. This will give you a single variable that you can use for the markers. Markers work on auxvariables and variables.

Theres actually an AuxKernel inside of Ferret that computes the magnitude of the polarization using the three variable inputs.  Seems like this is working fine with the ValueThreshold Marker.
Thanks for your suggestions!
